children.body: What helps me remember this word
Use the highlighter to grab words or phrases that help you make mental pictures about what you are reading.
For each word you grab, create a list of new words or phrases that create similar mental pictures.
Is my writing easy to understand and interesting?
Did I write more sentences to give my main ideas more meaning?
Do I think the beginning will make the reader want to keep reading?
When I read the ending, do any questions come into my head that are not answered in the story?
Do my ideas appear in the order that I want them to?
Organization (Did I think through the order?)
Do I know who will be reading my essay?
Does my writing sound friendly or is it matter-of-fact?
Did I use a lot of different words?
Word Choice (Did I make the best choices?)
Is the meaning of each sentence clear?
Are all of my sentences complete? Have I checked to make sure there are no sentence fragments or incomplete sentences?
Sentence Fluency (Did I put my sentences together correctly?)
Did I use punctuation, spelling and capitalization correctly?

6 Traits® Style - Writing Checklist for.body: 6 Traits Style Writing Checklist for Elementary School

children.body: Is my writing clear, focused and interesting?
Do my main ideas have supporting details?
Does the beginning make me want to read more?
Does the ending leave me with unanswered questions that should be answered?
Did I change topics smoothly (transition), or are my transitions from one topic to the next topic choppy?
Do my ideas appear in an order that will make sense to the readers?
Do I know who will be reading my essay?
Did I make a purposeful choice of the tone I will use so that readers will understand it?
Is my writing tone consistently friendly and personal (i.e., closeness) or is it matter-of-fact (i.e., academic)?
Does my writing try to involve the reader in the story?
Are my words interesting, strong, powerful, and accurate?
Did I use a wide range of words?
Do my words create lively images in the reader's mind?
As I re-read my story, do the words send the message that I want to send?
Do my sentences flow together easily when I read aloud?
Should I re-write any sentences to make the meaning more clear?
Are there any sentence fragments (i.e., incomplete sentences)?
Are there any boring or confusing sentences?
Did I use punctuation, spelling and capitalization correctly?
Did I choose good paragraph breaks so that my essay is organized?

6 Traits® Style - Writing Practice for M.body: 6 Traits Style - Writing Practice for Middle School

children.body: Purpose: set up and state your claim
Make your introductory paragraph interesting. How can you draw your readers in?
What background information, if any, does your reader need to know in order to understand your claim?
Literary work - state the author's name and title
Issue or theory - provide a brief explanation of your issue/theory
State your claim at the end of the introductory paragraph
Lay the foundation for proving your argument
Background Paragraph (if not included in intro)
Topic Sentence: One item, fact, detail, or example that will help your readers better understand your claim/topic.
State Evidence: Supporting reasons, examples, facts, statistics, and/or quotations to prove/support/explain your topic sentence.
Explain Evidence: How should the reader interpret the evidence? How does it prove your claim?
Concluding Sentence: Reassert how the topic sentence helps the reader understand and/or prove your paper's overall claim.
Supporting Evidence 1- To prove your argument
Topic Sentence: One item, fact, detail, or example that will help your readers better understand your claim/topic.
State Evidence: Supporting reasons, examples, facts, statistics, and/or quotations to prove/support/explain your topic sentence.
Explain Evidence: How should the reader interpret the evidence? How does it prove your claim?
Concluding Sentence: Reassert how the topic sentence helps the reader understand and/or prove your paper's overall claim.
Supporting Evidence 2 - To prove your argument
Topic Sentence: One item, fact, detail, or example that will help your readers better understand your claim/topic.
State Evidence: Supporting reasons, examples, facts, statistics, and/or quotations to prove/support/explain your topic sentence.
Explain Evidence: How should the reader interpret the evidence? How does it prove your claim?
Concluding Sentence: Reassert how the topic sentence helps the reader understand and/or prove your paper's overall claim.
Supporting Evidence Paragraph 3 - To prove your argument
Arguments against your claim and/or an aspect of your reasoning.
Concluding sentence that reasserts your claim.
Remind readers of your argument and supporting evidence.
restate your paper's overall claim and supporting evidence.
Why should the reader care about your claim?
What is the significance of your claim?
Why is it important to you as the writer?
Why is it important to the reader?
What should the reader take away from your claim?
Preview the text by looking at the headings and images.
What do you know about the topic?
What is the main gist of the text?
How did the author organize the text?

What literary devices were used and were they effective? (alliteration, allusion, anaphora, antithesis, euphemism, foreshadowing, hyperbole, idiom, imagery, metaphor, oxymoron, parallelism, personification, satire, simile, understatement)
What is the quality of the evidence?
Was data used? How was it used?
Were there visuals (diagrams, tables, illustrations)? How were they used?
Pick a word or phrase that you find interesting. Why did the author chose that word or phrase?
What does it have to say about my life or my world?
How do I feel about the quality of this work? (aesthetically and/or substantively)
How does this text connect to other texts I know?
What in the text tells me this?
Go back and view your claims. Ask yourself...
Record: Record your notes using telegraphic sentences (5 words or less).
Questions: As soon as possible, think of questions based on the notes. Questions help clarify meanings, reveal relationships, establish continuity, and strengthen memory.
Recite: Looking at the questions, say aloud, in your own words, the answers to the questions, facts, or ideas.

Reflect: Reflect on the material by asking yourself questions. For example: What's the significance of these facts? What principle are they based on? How can I apply them? How do they fit in with what I already know? What's beyond them?
Review: Spend at least ten minutes every week reviewing all your previous notes.
Use the highlighter to select text or words you have questions about. Then create a note to ask your questions.
Use this structure to organize your thoughts while reading and/or to develop a paragraph.
Power 4 = Detail or supportive information for Power 3. above.
Power 3 = Detail or supportive information for Power 2 above.
Power 2 = Detail or supportive information for Power 1 above.
Power 1 = Main Idea of the information.
Use the highlighter to grab text that fits under each category. Add a note with your thoughts, if desired.
What the character says or does.
What kind of person is the character?

What do I make connections with?

On the Day of the Event.

children.body: This is not what I intended to say.
This is not useful to my paper.
People may not understand this part.
People won't be interested in this part.
Diagnose: What best describes the sentence?
Have I Capitalized the first word and proper nouns?
Have I used end Punctuation, commas, and semicolons correctly?
Do the words look like they are Spelled right? Can I sound them out, or should I use a dictionary?
Capitals: Are first letters of sentences capitalized? Are proper nouns capitalized?
Punctuation: Is there punctuation at the end of each sentence?
Spelling: Find words (if any) that are not spelled correctly
Check the writer's paper for errors in:
Is the text primarily about a person, place, or thing?
Which person, place, or thing is being discussed?
What is the  main thing being said about the person, place, or thing?
Write a sentence restating what the paragraph is about.
What are you being asked to write about?
Work from your plan to develop your thesis statement.
Try to use different kinds of sentences.
Use PLANS to plan your paper.
Check to see that each goal was met.
List your ideas about the topic.
Activate the paragraph with a topic sentence.
End with a concluding sentence and Evaluate your work.
What do I already know about my topic? (Brainstorm)
How do I group my ideas?
What is my paper mainly about?
What do I like best? Explain why.
What parts are not clear? Why aren't they clear?
Is the paper interesting? Why or why not?
Question yourself to check organization. Did I:
What parts do I want to change?
Write two or more questions for my editor.
Decide on the suggestions to use.
List ideas for making your paper more interesting to your reader(s).
Think about making your paper more interesting.
On your first draft, make all changes that you think will improve your paper. Use ideas from the lists you have made.
Use the speak tool to listen to the writing.
Tell what the writing is about and what you liked best.
Read it again and make notes.
Read the first draft of your essay.
Find the sentence that tells what you believe. Is it clear?
Add two more reasons why you believe it.
Is it Connected to my belief or central idea?
Suspend judgment. Brainstorm ideas for and against the topic.
Take a side. Decide which side you are going to take: For or Against.
Organize ideas. Organize your ideas For and Against, you plan to use, and those you plan to refute
Plan more as you write. Remember to use DARE to see if you used all four parts.
Reject arguments for the other side.
Reject arguments for the other side.

SRSD - STOP and DARE into POW.body: SRSD - STOP and DARE into POW

children.body: STOP: Stop and Think Of Purposes.
LIST: List Ideas and Sequence Them.
Think of a story that you would like to share with others.
Who is the main character; who else is in the story?
When does the story take place?
Where does the story take place?
What does the main character want to do; what do the other characters want to do?
What happens when the main character tries to do it; what happens with the other characters?
How does the  main character feel; how do other characters feel?
Make notes of your ideas for each part.
Write your story - use good parts, add, elaborate, or revise as you write or afterward, and make sense.

SRSD - Story Grammar - WWW W=2 H=2.body: SRSD - Story Grammar - WWW W=2 H=2

children.body: What important things did the writer say about the main idea?
Go back and check to make sure I understand what the main idea was and the important things the writer said about this.
What is the main idea or topic that I am going to write about? Write a topic sentence for my summary.
How should I group my ideas? Organize my ideas.
Is there any important information that I left out, and is there any unimportant information that I can take out?
Write a summary about what I read.
Read my summary and think: Is there anything that is not clear? Rewrite my summary (if necessary).
Ask someone else to read my summary and ask them if there is anything that is not clear. Rewrite my summary (if necessary).
Topic sentence - tell the reader what you will be explaining.
Important Details - tell the reader 3 important ideas about the topic you are explaining.
Ending - bring everything together and remind the reader of your topic and all the important ideas.
Why am I writing this paper?
List a variety of good words for my story.
Write my story - Use good words and make sure my story makes sense.
Read over my story and ask - Did I write a good story?
Fix my story - Can I use more good words?
